Enhancing catalytic activity through self-assembled hydrogen-bonded organic framework-based catalysts at liquid/liquid interface for 4-nitrophenol reduction and energy challenges in methanol fuel cell Golandam Askarisarvestani Investigation a S. Hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks (HOFs) are pure organic framework structures endowed with appropriate flexibility and porosity, which have attracted special attention in the field of energy and water, air, and soil remediation. In this study, six HOF-based materials were synthesized as thin film at the liquid/liquid (toluene/water) interface and characterized by FT-IR, Raman, UV–Vis, PXRD, ICP, AFM, SEM, TGA, and BET techniques. The self-assembled HOF-based thin films were employed as catalysts for the 4-nitrophenol removal from water medium and, for the first time, for methanol oxidation of fuel cell, with satisfying results. Simultaneous in situ catalyst formation and 4-nitrophenol reduction occurred in the case of Pt(0)@HOF thin film, but an extraordinary removal (not reduction) occurred in the presence of Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film by formation of a new HOF from trimesic acid and 4-nitrophenol. Successful reduction of 4-nitrophenol occurred also in the presence of freshly prepared Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF catalysts (ex situ strategy). The chemical and thermal stability of HOF structure was improved by the interpenetration of ZIF-8 crystal structure, by increasing the hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking in the presence of 2-methylimidazole. The interpenetration of ZIF-8 to the crystal structure of HOF caused a significant decrease of the pore diameter of the structure. These pores acted as specific sites for the guest molecules, and their dimensions did not permit 4-nitrophenol to penetrate into the cavity of structures whereas allowed methanol penetration into these cavities due to its smaller size. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract The synthesis of stable HOF-based catalysts at a liquid-liquid interface is a significant achievement in the field of catalysis. These thin films, prepared using a novel approach, demonstrate considerable catalytic activity for addressing two important challenges: water pollution and energy. Keywords Hydrogen-bonded organic framework Platinum nanostructures Metal-organic framework 4-nitrophenol reduction Fuel cell Liquid-liquid interface Water remediation Methanol oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Important sources of water pollution in the world are nitrophenol derivatives, which are used as raw materials for pharmaceutical, leather, pesticide, dye, textile, etc. industries [1–9]. 4-Nitrophenol, due to its high toxicity, high stability and resistance to degradation causes serious pollution in the atmosphere, water, and soil, which results in the interaction of this substance with the proteins of the body's organisms and causes skin and respiratory diseases or even coma [10]. Therefore, efforts are being made to remove nitrophenols from wastewater either by adsorption or converting (reducing) it to less toxic substances such as aminophenols [11–14]. Ion exchange [15], co-precipitation [16], membrane separation [17] and adsorption [18] techniques have been applied to remove pollutants from wastewater. Adsorption of water pollutants onto porous materials is a significant remediation procedure due to the low-cost, facile recycling, high efficiency, and fast kinetics advantages. Interesting candidates for adsorbing water pollutants are metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) a unique class of materials made up with various organic linkers and metal clusters. Large surface area, super porous structure, well-defined architecture, and structural flexibility are some of the beneficial properties of this class of materials [19–23]. Covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) and hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks (HOFs) are other porous materials able to absorb water pollutants. HOFs are gaining more and more interest in the scientific community as they overcome some disadvantages of MOF or COF structures such as instability of some of the MOFs in aqueous medium, toxicity of some metal nodes in the MOF structures and drug delivery restriction, as well as low crystallinity and strict reaction conditions for the synthesis of COFs [24]. HOFs are produced through intermolecular hydrogen-bonding of self-assembled discrete molecular tectons with N-donor and O-donor containing organic ligands or metal-organic building units [25–27]. The architecture of HOF is governed by the flexible and weak hydrogen bonding interactions which, in turn, may affect the application of HOFs [28]. There are some reports on pore modulation of HOFs for propylene capture, separation and purification [29,30], one-pot synthesis of meso‑tetra(carboxy-phenyl)-porphyrin based-HOFs with interesting stability and permanent porosity [31], ultrasonic-assisted formation of 3D HOF made up of heme-like ligand (meso‑tetra(carboxy-phenyl)-porphyrin), 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) (co-former) and 1D porous ribbons with excellent surface sensitivity [32], formation of similar HOFs via counter-strategy by blocking the strong hydrogen-bond building units on meso‑tetra(carboxy-phenyl)-porphyrin backbones applied for photocatalytic degradation of 9,10-diphenylanthracene [33] or dehydration of industrial gases [34]. Facile synthesis [35], regeneration by self-healing [35], lower density and toxicity [35] than MOFs, facile growing of the single crystals due to the weaker interactions and easier design of frameworks [36] than COFs are the advantages of HOFs. But weaker hydrogen bonds in HOFs in comparison with the coordination bonds in MOFs or covalent bonds in COFs leads to the easy collapse of the pores after the activation of HOF structures by removing the solvents [24]. Furthermore, the weaker hydrogen bonds in HOFs cannot provide sufficient energy required to form a totally stable structure with permanent pores [24]. Increasing the number of hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions leads to increasing the thermal and chemical stability of HOFs and maintaining the porous structure even after the guest solvent molecules leave the host structure [11,25]. Another route to increase the stability of HOF structures is the formation of metallized HOFs [37]. In addition to increasing their stability, the adjustability of metallized HOFs will increase and lead to the formation of different kinds of catalysts useful in the fields of environment pollution and energy [37]. A reason why HOFs have received less attention in comparison to MOFs or COFs in the field of materials is related to the methods used for the preparation of HOFs [11] and this pressures research to find convenient synthetic methods to form that yield HOFs with desired catalytic properties. A heterogeneous liquid-liquid interface system formed in the presence of solvents with different solvation properties provides an interesting medium with unique chemical, morphological, kinetic, and structural characteristics. A wide range of applications in catalysis, separations science, electrochemical processes and nanodevices make the liquid-liquid interfaces the focal point of new research [38,39]. Interface with few nanometers thickness constitutes an excellent scaffold for the self-assembly of nanostructures and manipulation to explore novel properties. Molecular dynamic simulations demonstrated that the interface between the two liquids is a sheet of vacuum that is between liquid slabs and applies as a 2D space for the synthesis, functionalization, or polymerization of various structures such as alloys, Janus particles and capsules with distinctive properties via changing the surface energy of particles [40]. Self-assembly at liquid-liquid interface can be controlled by the interfacial tension of two immiscible liquids, choosing a proper inorganic/organic couple of precursors, stabilizers, and hydrogen bonding. The nanoparticles stability at the interface is affected by the precursor concentration, the volume ratio of two immiscible liquids and the polarity of the organic phase [41]. Herein we report on the facile synthesis of platinized HOF-based thin film (Pt@HOF), interpenetrated frameworks of zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 with HOF thin film (Pt@ZIF-8@HOF) or π-π stacking interactions of 2-methylimidazole with HOF thin film (Pt@2-methylimidazole@HOF) at toluene-water interface and room temperature. ZIFs, one of the important classes of MOFs with the both advantages of zeolites and MOFs, exhibit high porosity, crystallinity, robust bonding structure, chemical and hydrothermal stability, high surface area and structural tailorability. Among ZIFs, ZIF-8 (made from 2-methylimidazole linker and Zn(II) precursor with a special molar ratio) shows unique advantages such as various and facile synthesis strategies, high stability, cheap and available starting materials, and most importantly, the ability of formation at the toluene-water interface in the form of a thin film make it interesting and the best choice for our investigation. The application of these thin films, along with that of Pt(0)-trimesic acid and Pt(0)-melamine thin films, in the reduction/ removal of 4-nitrophenol from water medium and in the methanol oxidation in the anodic part of direct methanol fuel cells are also described. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials, methods and instrumentation Trimesic acid, melamine, 2-methylimidazole, [Zn(acac)2] (acac: acetylacetonate) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. [PtCl2(cod)] (cod: cis,cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene) was synthesized according to literature [42]. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum RX I instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the prepared thin films were recorded with the 2θ angle range between 5°−90° using a Bruker AXS D8 Avance diffractometer. Theoretical XRD data were obtained applying 3D visualization program for structural models (VESTA) software. Raman spectra were recorded on a Horiba confocal Raman Lab Ram HR spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and energy dispersive analysis of X-ray (EDAX) data were obtained using a TESCAN VEGA 3 instrument. Atomic force microscopy analysis (AFM) was carried out using a Brisk ARA AFM microscope. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using a Perkin Elmer STA6000 thermal analyzer, and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller analysis (BET) was carried out using a MicrotracBEL Corp BELSORP mini II equipment. The UV–Vis spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer Lambda 25 spectrophotometer. 2.2 Synthesis of HOF Trimesic acid-based HOF was synthesized with a modified literature procedure [43]. In a typical experiment, trimesic acid (8.3 mg, 0.0396 mmol) and melamine (14.9 mg, 0.1188 mmol) in a 1:3 molar ratio were sonicated individually in distilled water (12.5 mL) for 5 min and mixed with each other using an ultrasonic bath. A light white precipitate was formed rapidly. The reaction solvent was removed using a dropper and the resulting solid (HOF) was repeatedly washed with distilled water and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum oven over night. 2.3 Pt(0)@HOF, Pt(0)-trimesic acid and Pt(0)-melamine thin films Trimesic acid (8.3 mg, 0.0396 mmol) and melamine (14.9 mg, 0.1188 mmol) were sonicated individually in distilled water (12.5 mL) for 5 min and then mixed with each other in an ultrasonic bath. A beaker (100 mL) was filled with the aqueous solution containing HOF as the lower phase followed by the dropwise addition of a toluene solution of [PtCl2(cod)] (9.3 mg, 0.0248 mmol, 25 mL, 0.99 mM) as the organic upper phase. Then, 5.0 mL of an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride 0.10 M was added dropwise. After 24 h the aqueous phase turned colorless from white (as shown in SI2) and a black Pt(0)@HOF thin film formed at the interface. The same procedure was followed for the synthesis of Pt(0)-trimesic acid (starting from trimesic acid, 33 mg, 0.158 mmol in 25 mL H2O) and Pt(0)-melamine (starting from melamine, 20 mg, 0.158 mmol, in 25 mL H2O) thin films. 2.4 ZIF-8@HOF thin film Solid 2-methylimidazole (324 mg, 3.94 mmol) was added to 25 mL of an aqueous colloidal solution of trimesic acid (8.3 mg, 0.0396 mmol) and melamine (14.9 mg, 0.1188 mmol). A reaction beaker was filled with this colorless aqueous solution (25 mL) as the lower phase and a [Zn(acac)2] solution in toluene (104 mg, 0.394 mmol, 25 mL, 15.7 mM) was added dropwise, forming the organic upper phase. After 24 h a white film of ZIF-8@HOF formed at the interface. 2.5 Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film The reaction procedure was similar to Section 2.4, but [PtCl2(cod)] (9.3 mg, 0.0248 mmol) was also dissolved in the toluene solution of [Zn(acac)2]. After the organic and aqueous phases were stabilized, a sodium borohydride aqueous solution (0.10 M, 5 mL) was added dropwise causing, after 24 h, the formation of a gray thin film of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF at the toluene/water interface. 2.6 Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film This reaction procedure was similar to Section 2.5, but in the absence of [Zn(acac)2] in the organic phase. A black thin film of Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF was formed completely after 24 h. 2.7 Reduction/removal of 4-nitrophenol 2.7.1 In situ thin film formation At room temperature, a quartz cuvette (3.0 mL) was filled with an aqueous solution of 4-nitrophenol (0.057 mM, 1.4 mL) containing trimesic acid (0.40 mg, 0.0019 mmol) and melamine (0.83 mg, 0.0065 mmol) as the bottom phase followed by the dropwise addition of a toluene solution of [PtCl2(cod)] (1.0 mM, 1.4 mL) as the upper phase. After the stabilization of two phases, an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride (10 mM, 280 µL) was injected which led to the formation of Pt(0)@HOF thin film and to the contemporary reduction of 4-nitrophenol, as monitored by UV–Vis spectroscopy. Similar procedures were followed in the case of other systems starting from the following reagents: 4-nitrophenol (0.057 mM, 1.4 mL), trimesic acid (1.8 mg, 0.0085 mmol) and [PtCl2(cod)] (1.0 mM, 1.4 mL), Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film; 4-nitrophenol (0.057 mM, 1.4 mL), melamine (1.1 mg, 0.0087 mmol) and [PtCl2(cod)] (1.0 mM, 1.4 mL), Pt(0)-melamine thin film; 4-nitrophenol (0.057 mM, 1.4 mL), trimesic acid (0.4 mg, 0.0019 mmol), melamine (0.83 mg, 0.0065 mmol), 2-methylimidazole (18.1 mg, 0.2204 mmol) and [PtCl2(cod)] (1.0 mM, 1.4 mL), Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film. 2.7.2 Reduction of 4-nitrophenol in the presence of freshly prepared Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF thin films (ex situ procedure) The upper toluene phase of the thin films prepared as described in Section 2.3. was removed using a dropper and the aqueous phase was let to stand for 2 h and then centrifugated to produce freshly prepared Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF thin films. A quartz cuvette (3.0 mL) was filled with an aqueous solution of 4-nitrophenol (0.2 mM, 1.7 mL) and sodium borohydride (15 mM, 0.7 mL). The catalyst (100 µL) was then added into the cuvette and the progress of the reduction reaction was monitored by UV–Vis spectroscopy. 2.8 Electrocatalytic methanol oxidation After polishing the surface of glassy carbon electrode and sonicating it in an ethanol/water mixture, the as-prepared thin films were transferred onto the surface of the glassy carbon electrode with the aid of glassy lamella [39]. To do this, upper toluene phase was removed by a dropper, a piece of the as-synthesized film was moved to the surface of glassy lamella and transferred to the surface of this electrode using no nafion and dried at room temperature. This is the modified working electrode. Ag/AgCl and platinum wire were used as reference and counter electrodes. Cyclic voltammograms were recorded with an Autolab Potentiostat Galvanostat in 0.50 M H2SO4 and CH3OH in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF thin films and 0.50 M NaOH and CH3OH in the case of ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films. 3 Results and discussion The HOF structure was synthesized via a facile and fast method using aqueous solution of trimesic acid and melamine at room temperature. The catalytic activity and the stability of HOF system were increased by the addition of platinum nanoparticles, ZIF-8 and 2-methylimidazole. Removal of the guest solvent molecules from the porous structure of HOFs and thermal/vacuum activation of these structures can afford three kinds of materials with the following structures (Fig. 1 ): (i) formation of nonporous amorphous structures and loss of the well-ordered arrangement (Fig. 1a) which is undesirable; (ii) formation of supramolecular polymorphs with less porosity than the initial HOF structures, which have the ability to rearrange the crystal network (Fig. 1b), also undesirable; (iii) formation of well-ordered structure with enduring porosity and stability (Fig. 1c) which is desirable. In this work, three strategies were applied to form chemically and thermally stable HOFs with permanent porosity at liquid/liquid interface, which are: (i) stabilization by platinum nanoparticles that led to the formation of platinized HOF (Pt(0)@HOF) thin film (Fig. 1d); (ii) stabilization by interpenetrated frameworks of ZIF-8 that led to the formation of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Fig. 1e); (iii) stabilization by π-π stacking interactions of 2-methylimidazole that led to the formation of Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film (Fig. 1f). Pt@HOF thin film was stabilized structurally and chemically by the presence of platinum nanoparticles. Encapsulation of nanoparticles in the porous structure of HOFs preserved the stability of the structures even after solvent removal from the cavities. In the case of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film, ZIF-8 framework interpenetrated with the HOF framework and formed a stronger structure. In the case of Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film, non-covalent π-π stacking interactions between the aromatic rings of 2-methyl imidazole, trimesic acid and melamine stabilized the HOF structures. In this work, six kinds of thin films were self-assembled at toluene-water interface. The resulting materials were characterized and applied as catalysts in 4-nitrophenol reduction/ removal and methanol oxidation processes. Figure S1a illustrates the formation of Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film (TF1) at toluene-water interface by addition of sodium borohydride to the trimesic acid/[PtCl2(cod)] biphasic system (1–4 steps) and shows the hydrogen bonds formed between trimesic acid moieties [44]. An analogous procedure, starting from the melamine/[PtCl2(cod)] biphasic system, led to the synthesis of the Pt(0)-melamine thin film TF2 (Figure S1b) [45,46]. Figure S1c (1–4 steps) illustrates the facile formation of HOF in aqueous medium at room temperature from trimesic acid and melamine [43]. In order to stabilize HOFs, in situ synthesis and encapsulation of Pt(0) nanoparticles (deriving from NaBH4 reduction of [PtCl2(cod)]) into the porous structure of HOF was carried out (TF3, Figure S1d). Interpenetration of ZIF-8 (formed by reaction of [Zn(acac)2] and 2-methylimidazole) and HOF (formed from trimesic acid and melamine), which helped fine-tune the porosity of the final material, gave rise to ZIF-8@HOF thin film (TF4, Figure S1e). Figure S1f shows the formation of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF stabilized structure (TF5) while Figure S1g shows the formation of Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film stabilized by π-π stacking interactions (TF6). 3.1 FT-IR study FT-IR analysis of TF1–5 is shown in Fig. 2 . Fig. 2a and d show the FT-IR spectra of pure trimesic acid and of Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film, respectively, with attributions [47,48]. The formation of new intermolecular hydrogen bonds in Pt(0)-trimesic acid affects the CO stretching vibration band (blue-shifted to 1380 cm–1), the OH stretching vibration (which gives a very broad band at 3300–3500 cm–1) and the symmetrical CO vibration (split into two bands at 520 and 600 cm–1) [49]. The asymmetrical CO vibration band split into bands at 1710 and 1620 cm–1, presumably due to the interaction of platinum nanoparticles with carboxylate groups [48] and is in accordance with the structure depicted in Figure S1a (step 4). Fig. 2b and e show the FT-IR spectra of pure melamine and of the Pt(0)-melamine thin film, respectively, with attributions [50]. The FT-IR spectrum of the Pt(0)-melamine thin film shows smoother peaks in the 400–800 cm–1 region (CNH2), with respect to pure melamine, confirming pre-polymerization of melamine, as depicted in the structure reported in Figure S1b (step 4). Furthermore, changes in the absorptions in the range of 3300–3600 cm–1 (free and hydrogen bonded NH2) suggest the presence of interaction between the NH2 groups of melamine and platinum nanoparticles. In the FT-IR spectrum of HOF (Fig. 2c) no peaks ascribable to free NH2 are present, with absorptions due to hydrogen bonded NH2 at 3430–3480 cm–1 that appear broader and smoother in comparison with those of melamine, because of hydrogen bonds formation between trimesic acid and melamine. Hydrogen bonds between trimesic acid and melamine are also responsible for the shift of triazine ring vibration band from 820 cm–1 in melamine to 790 cm–1 in the as-synthesized HOF [43]. Furthermore, the CO stretching vibration band is shifted from 1720 cm−1 in trimesic acid to 1700 cm–1 in the HOF [43] and supports the structure depicted in Figure S1c (step 4). A broad band at 3180 cm–1 is related to asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of OH while the HOH bending vibration band is observed in 1530 cm–1 and confirms the embedding of water molecules [43]. The FT-IR spectrum of Pt(0)@HOF thin film (Fig. 2f) strongly resembles that of HOF, with the CO vibration band split into two peaks at 1810 and 1650 cm–1, presumably due to the interaction of metallic platinum nanoparticles with carboxylate groups [48]. Fig. 2g exhibits the FT-IR spectrum of ZIF-8 thin film with imidazole ring stretching bands in the range of 1350–1500 cm–1, imidazole ring plane bands at around 900–1350 cm–1, imidazole ring out of plane bands in the range of 400–800 cm–1, stretching band of ZnN at about 600 cm–1, and CH bonds stretching at 2943 and 3140 cm–1 [51]. In the FT-IR spectra of ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Fig. 2h) and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Fig. 2i) all the characteristic peaks of ZIF-8 and HOF are present, confirming that the supramolecular structures are preserved (Figure S1e,f, step 4). Figure S2a shows the FT-IR spectra of Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film (TF6). 3.2 Raman study Figure S3a-d shows the Raman spectra of the as-synthesized HOF, ZIF-8, ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films, respectively. In the case of HOF (Figure S3a), the aromatic ring CH vibration modes of trimesic acid are observable at 926 (in-plane) and 978 (out-of-plane) cm–1. The bands at 1662 and 1700 cm–1 are assigned to C = O stretching of trimesic acid. CO stretching mode of trimesic acid appears at 1211 cm–1. CC stretching bands for the trimesic acid ring appear at 1002, 1443 and 1605 cm–1. Out-of-plane vibration bands of trimesic acid ring are at 308 and 401 cm−1 [49]. These peaks confirm the presence of trimesic acid in the HOF structure. Presence of the D and G bands at 1439 and 1600 cm–1 with the (I D/I G) ratio of 2.6 is observed [37]. D band is related to defect in the structure and rises from out-of-plane vibrations. G band originates from the CC bond in-plane vibration from the sp2 orbital [52]. The characteristic peak at 683 cm–1 is observed for in-plane deformation vibration of the triazine ring and a peak at 797 cm–1 is observed for CN bending vibration of melamine [53,54]. These peaks confirm the presence of melamine in the HOF structure. Figure S3b shows the Raman spectra of ZIF-8 thin film with ZnN stretching band at 170 cm–1, imidazole ring puckering band at 683 cm–1, CN stretching band at 1140 cm–1, and methyl bending absorption at 1458 cm–1 [55]. Figure S3c,d shows the Raman spectra of ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films, respectively, wherein the peaks related to the presence of HOF are labeled with a ● sign and peaks related to the presence of ZIF-8 are labeled with a * sign. The I D/I G ratio is increased in the case of ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films that is comparable with the ratio obtained for HOF. Missing the G band in the Raman is related to the elongation of the CC bonds along the longitudinal axis, indicating a more disordered carbon skeleton in ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films in comparison with HOF that can be due to the encapsulation of platinum nanoparticles and interpenetration of ZIF-8 crystals and HOF [37]. 3.3 UV–Vis study Figures S3e-f show the UV–Vis spectra of (i) trimesic acid, (ii) melamine, (iii) HOF, (iv) ZIF-8, (v) ZIF@HOF and (vi) Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF. ZIF-8 thin film showed a characteristic peak at 212.0 nm. In addition, a broad and weak hump between 485.0 and 680.0 nm was present which is related to the interactions of ethanol solvent molecules with the framework of ZIF-8 [56] (Figure S3f, iv). To study the intermolecular interactions, UV–Vis spectra were recorded for ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films (Figure S3 (v, vi)). These spectra showed two absorption peaks at 205.0 nm (n to π* transition of carbonyl group on the trimesic acid) and 283.0 nm (π to π* transition of melamine ring) in the case of ZIF-8@HOF and 205.0 nm (n to π* transition of carbonyl group on the trimesic acid) and 280.0 nm (π to π* transition of melamine ring) in the case of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films [57]. The peak in the region of 205.0 nm overlapped with the peak related to the presence of ZIF-8 and had a shift relative to it. In the case of melamine, one of the precursors applied for the HOF synthesis, the absorption peak at 206.6 nm (n to π* transition) and a weak shoulder at about 240.0 nm (π to π* transition, symmetry forbidden, vibrationally allowed) are present [58] (Figure S3 (e, ii)). The p-π conjugation may be formed between the double bond of melamine ring and the lone pair of the nitrogen atoms of amine groups in the melamine structure. This structure can form a hydrogen bonding with trimesic acid and produce a HOF structure. The decreasing of the n to π* energy transition from the wavelength of 206.6 nm in melamine to 208.0 nm in the HOF can be related to the hydrogen bond formation, that leads to the weakening of the p-π conjugation degree along with a bathochromic shift [57] (Figure S3e, inset diagrams). 3.4 PXRD study Fig. 3 a,b shows the theoretical XRD patterns of pure melamine (JCPDS No. 024-1654) [59] and trimesic acid (JCPDS No. 00-045-1880) [59], the precursors of HOF, respectively. Fig. 3c shows the experimental XRD pattern of HOF with Bragg reflections at 2θ = 8.50°, 13.50° and 26.0° that are consistent with reported data [60,61]. Fig. 3d shows the theoretical diffraction patterns obtained using VESTA software for Pt(0) (JCPDS No. 65–2868) [62] while XRD pattern of the as-synthesized Pt(0)@HOF thin film is shown in Fig. 3e with the platinum(0) Bragg reflections at 2θ = 40°, 48°, 68°, 82° and 86° that belong to [(111), (200), (220), (311) and (222)] planes, respectively. These diffraction patterns are consistent with the theoretical Pt(0) patterns (Fig. 3d). Presence of the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 13.3° and 26.0° related to [(001) and (210)] planes confirm the existence of HOF structure in the as-synthesized Pt(0)@HOF thin film. In the case of Pt(0)-melamine thin film, in addition to the diffraction peaks that confirm the presence of Pt(0) nanoparticles, the presence of some weak diffractions in the range of 2θ = 10°−30° confirms the presence of melamine in the structure and is in accord with the diffraction peaks shown by the theoretical data of melamine [59] (Fig. 3f-h). A similar trend was found in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film which confirms the presence of Pt(0) and trimesic acid in the as-prepared thin film (Fig. 3i-k). ZIF-8 thin film with [(011), (002), (112), (022), (013), (222), (233) and (134)] planes at 2θ = 7.1°, 10.2°, 12.5°, 14.4°, 16.3°, 17.9°, 24.1° and 26.7° is shown in Fig. 3l. These planes are consistent with the reported data for ZIF-8 crystal structure (JCPDS No. 00-062-1030) [51,63]. Fig. 3m shows the XRD patterns of ZIF-8@HOF thin film with all the peaks related to ZIF-8 (marked with *) and HOF (marked with ●) structures and confirms the successful synthesis of this thin film. The diffraction pattern of the as-synthesized Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film shows the presence of ZIF-8 (*) and HOF (●) in the thin film, but the Pt(0) diffraction peaks are not evident due to low metal loading. However, the presence of platinum nanoparticles in Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film was confirmed by EDAX, elemental mapping and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) (Table S1) analysis. 3.5 AFM and SEM study To study the surface topology, thickness and average surface roughness (Ra ) of the as-prepared thin films, an AFM analysis was carried out. The thickness and average surface roughness are 4.1 and 64.4 nm for Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film (Fig. 4 a1), 351.7 and 429.0 nm for Pt(0)-melamine thin film (Fig. 4b1), 3.6 and 123.9 nm for HOF porous structure (Fig. 4c1), 10.5 and 323.1 nm for Pt(0)@HOF thin film (Fig. 4d1), 93.6 and 176.4 nm for ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Fig. 4e1) and 496.5 and 135.6 nm in the case of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Fig. 4f1), respectively (Table 1 ). Comparison of the average surface roughness of HOF structure with Pt(0)@HOF thin film shows that the addition of platinum nanoparticles to the HOF structure caused a significant increase on this parameter, beneficial to the catalytic activity. In contrast, comparing the average surface roughness of ZIF-8@HOF thin film with Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film shows that the addition of Pt nanoparticles caused an unusual decrease of the average surface roughness, which is presumably due to the complete coverage of platinum nanostructures inside the porous structure of ZIF-8. Figure S4 shows the amplitude and 3-D topography images for the as-synthesized thin films. To investigate the morphology of the as-synthesized thin films, SEM analysis was carried out. In the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film, nanobowls were synthesized (Fig. 4a2). EDAX and elemental mapping analysis showed the presence of C, O and Pt elements with homogeneous dispersion (Figure S5). Nanospheres were formed in the case of Pt(0)-melamine thin film (Fig. 4b2) with a homogeneous dispersion of C, N and Pt elements (Figure S6). Well-ordered homogeneous nanoribbons were formed in the case of the as-synthesized HOF (Fig. 4c2). The presence of C, N and O elements was confirmed by EDAX and elemental mapping analysis (Fig. 5 ). Fig. 4d2 shows the formation of fine homogeneous spherical nanoparticles well dispersed on the surface for the Pt(0)@HOF thin film, with a homogeneous dispersion of C, N, O and Pt elements (Figure S7). Ribbon structure of HOF diffused with the rhombic dodecahedral structure of ZIF-8 is apparent in the case of ZIF-8@HOF which shows the mixed locked crystal structure for this thin film (Fig. 4e2) with C, O, N and Zn elements (Figure S8). Mesoporous coral-like structures are evident for the Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Figs. 4f2 and S9). EDAX and elemental mapping analysis of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film confirmed the presence of C, N, O, Zn and Pt elements in the structure (Figure S10). Figure S11 shows the SEM, EDAX and elemental mapping analysis of Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film with details. The consistency between the SEM images and the AFM data is very interesting and confirms the reported morphology for the as-synthesized films (Table 1). 3.6 Proposed mechanism of formation and assembly of platinum nanostructures at liquid-liquid interface In the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid nanobowls, aqueous phase containing trimesic acid and organic phase containing platinum precursors stay in contact with each other for minutes (Fig. 6 a). Trimesic acid molecules were self-assembled by hydrogen bonding at the interface (Fig. 6b) and formed spheres (Fig. 6c). Addition of NaBH4 causes the formation of Pt(0) nanoparticles onto the trimesic acid spheric structure (Fig. 6d). As time passes and reduction of platinum continues, solid nanospheres change to hollow nanobowls due to continuous diffusion [64] (Fig. 6e). Homogeneous nanobowls are formed after 24 h at toluene-water interface, as shown in Fig. 6f, displaying the SEM image of Pt(0)-trimesic acid structure. Nanospheres were formed in the case of Pt(0)-melamine thin film. Fig. 6 (g-l) shows the details of the proposed mechanism. After the stabilization of the two immiscible phases (Fig. 6g), melamine molecules moves toward the interface (due to the lower interfacial energy) and self-assembly to form a surface (Fig. 6h,i). Pt(0) nanoparticles are then formed by adding sodium borohydride as a reducing agent and decorate the surface of pre-polymerized and self-assembled melamine (Fig. 6j). Some Pt(0) nanoparticles fill the empty cavities of pre-polymerized melamine and some of them are involved in the formation of the skeleton of Pt(0)-melamine thin film due to the binding ability of Pt(0) and amino groups of melamine. Aggregation of smaller Pt(0) nanoparticles result in nanoparticles growth (Fig. 6k) which form numerous connected nanospheres after 24 h self-assembly and growth at the interface. Fig. 6l shows the SEM image of Pt(0)-melamine nanospheres. Self-assembly and hydrogen bonding formation of trimesic acid (Fig. 7 a) and melamine (Fig. 7b) leads to the formation of the initial crystal structure of HOF (Fig. 7c) that immediately grows (Fig. 7d). By diffusion, these crystal structures (depicted as spheres) finally create nanoribbon structures (Fig. 7e). Well-ordered nanoribbons of HOF are produced in aqueous medium at ambient temperature and pressure easily, in the form of cloudy white precipitates. Fig. 7f shows the SEM image of HOF nanoribbons. A possible mechanism for the formation of Pt(0)@HOF thin film is the following. Trimesic acid and melamine mixture in the aqueous phase and platinum precursor in the organic phase stay in contact with each other for a minute (Fig. 7g), self-assembly and form hydrogen bonds between trimesic acid and melamine at the interface resulting in the initial crystals of HOF (Fig. 7h). Growth of these crystals at the interface gives rise to the formation of the final HOF structure (Fig. 7i). Diffusion and self-assembly of HOF crystal layers forms a surface in the presence of toluene (Fig. 7j), while addition of sodium borohydride produces Pt(0) nanoparticles on the HOF surface (Fig. 7k). The formation of very fine and uniform spherical nanoparticles on the surface of Pt(0)@HOF thin film is shown in the SEM image displayed in Fig. 7l. The mechanism of formation of ZIF-8@HOF thin film follows presumably these steps: initially, trimesic acid, melamine and 2-methylimidazole in the water lower phase and [Zn(acac)2] in the toluene upper phase stay in contact with each other (Fig. 8 a); then, all the precursors from two phases move toward the interface with trimesic acid and melamine forming HOF initial crystal structure, and 2-methylimidazole and [Zn(acac)2] forming ZIF-8 crystal structures linked to the HOF structure (Fig. 8b). In the third step, the primitive hybrid crystal structure of ZIF-8/HOF self-assemble (Fig. 8c). In the fourth step, HOF structures (spheres) diffuse and form a ribbon-like structure locked and interpenetrated with the cubic structure of ZIF-8 crystals (Fig. 8d). As time goes by, and continuing the diffusion process, cubic structures with truncated edges are formed [65] which evolve into rhombic dodecahedral structures of ZIF-8 interpenetrated with HOF nanoribbons (Fig. 8e). The formation of ribbons interpenetrated with the rhombic dodecahedral structures in the Pt(0)@HOF thin film is shown in the SEM picture displayed in Fig. 8f. In the case of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film, a mesoporous coral-like structure made up of porous nanobowls was detected, which can be formed with the following mechanism. Toluene solution of [PtCl2(cod)] and [Zn(acac)2] stay in contact with the aqueous solution of trimesic acid, melamine and 2-methylimidazole (Fig. 8g); then, these precursors move toward the interface due to the lower interfacial energy giving rise to formation of HOF initial crystals (from trimesic acid and melamine) and ZIF-8 crystals (from [Zn(acac)2] and 2-methylimidazole). These crystal structures are locked and form a stable spherical structure (Fig. 8h) onto which platinum(0) nanoparticles settle (Fig. 8i). As time goes by and the Pt reduction continues, some of the solid nanospheres convert into hollow nanobowls due to continuous diffusion (Fig. 8j). Self-assembly, growth and diffusion of some of the solid nanospheres produces coral-like structures [66] (Fig. 8k). The formation of porous coral-like structures of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films is shown in the SEM picture displayed in Fig. 8l. The TEM image of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF (Fig. 9 ) clearly shows the core-shell structure, with platinum and ZIF-8 placed in the core and HOF placed in the shell. 3.7 Porosity N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and BET analysis (Figs. 10 a-g, S12a-d) was carried out to study the porosity of the as-synthesized thin films. Encapsulation of platinum nanoparticles in the porous structures affects the pore types, diameters, volumes and even surface areas. The relevant results are collected in Table 1. Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film gave a BET surface area of 7.7 m2·g–1, an average pore diameter of 10.5 nm and a pore volume of 0.020 cm3·g–1 (Figure S12), whereas these values were 6.9 m2·g–1, 11.4 nm and 0.020 cm3·g–1, respectively, in the case of Pt(0)-melamine thin film (Figure S12). A BET surface area of 13.9 m2·g–1, an average pore diameter of 7.1 nm and a pore volume of 0.025 cm3·g–1 was obtained in the case of HOF thin film (Fig. 10a-c), that is comparable with the data obtained for similar HOFs formed from relatively harsh conditions and hard and time-consuming strategies (Table 1). In fact, small surface areas should be packed pores between the network constructed by thin fibers or particles. The platinized HOF thin film Pt(0)@HOF had a BET surface area of 4.6 m2·g–1, average pore diameter of 8.5 nm and a pore volume of 0.010 cm3·g–1 (Fig. 10a-c). Comparing the pore diameter and pore volume of Pt(0)@HOF with HOF confirms the presence of platinum nanoparticles in the cavities of HOF structure. Interpenetrated ZIF-8 frameworks and HOF crystals produced a strong hybrid crystal structure with improved characteristics (BET surface area of 871.1 m2·g–1, average pore diameter of 1.8 nm and pore volume of 0.390 cm3·g–1, Fig. 10d-g and Table 1) in comparison with individual ZIF-8 and HOF structures (Table 1). Encapsulation of Pt(0) nanoparticles in the porous structure of ZIF-8@HOF thin film led to stretch the cavity of the porous structure and also increased the BET surface area of the thin film. The BET surface area of ZIF-8@HOF was 1101.2 m2·g–1, the average pore diameter was 1.9 nm and the pore volume was 0.535 cm3·g–1 (Fig. 10d-g). The N2 adsorption isotherms displayed “Type-IV” behavior. The t-plot method gave the amount of microporous and mesoporous volumes. The (t) parameter refers to the thickness of the adsorbed layer on the surface. The diagram intercept was zero in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF thin films, which confirms the presence of only mesopores in the structures. The shape of the hysteresis loops confirms the existence of slit-like pores in the structures. The high constant value of (C) indicates a stronger N2 adsorption on the surface of the as-synthesized thin films in comparison with polymers or metals. This value is 315 for Pt(0)-trimesic acid, 45 for Pt(0)-melamine, 65 for HOF, 54 for Pt(0)@HOF, 1594 for ZIF-8@HOF and 753 for Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films. 3.8 Thermogravimetric analysis The thermal stability of the as-synthesized catalysts was studied by TGA analysis (Fig. 11 ). Weight losses for ZIF-8@HOF (Fig. 11c1) and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films (Fig. 11c2) were observed at about 170 °C and in the range of 350–580 °C. In the case of HOF (Fig. 11b), the weight loss occurred in three main steps: (i) weight loss of 10 % appeared at around 125 °C and is related to the loss of water, (ii) weight loss of 32.92 % appeared at around 345 °C and is related to the loss of trimesic acid and (iii) weight loss of 45.72 % appeared at around 485 °C and is related to the loss of melamine [43]. The ratio of weight losses between melamine and trimesic acid proposed the molar ratio of 1.38:1 for these two materials and the presence of N-/O- and N-/N- heterocyclic structures formed by hydrogen bonding is confirmed. It is interesting the note that the residual content of sample after heating at 900 °C is 0 % of the initial weight in the case of HOF structure, 71.14 % in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid (Fig. 11a1), 64.16 % in the case of Pt(0)-melamine (Fig. 11a2), 84.96 % in the case of Pt(0)@HOF (Fig. 11a3), 36.34 % in the case of ZIF-8@HOF (Fig. 11c1) and 34.69 % in the case of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films (Fig. 11c2), indicating a significantly higher thermal stability of the stabilized HOFs (platinized HOF and interpenetrated ZIF-8@HOF) with respect to the “naked” HOF structure. 3.9 Catalytic activity of the as-synthesized thin films 3.9.1 Removal/reduction of 4-nitrophenol in water medium Removal of 4-nitrophenol from water medium was investigated as a model reaction for the abatement of nitrophenol derivatives from wastewaters and the details on the catalytic activity of the investigated thin films are reported as Supplementary Information (Figures S13-S24). Addition of aqueous NaBH4 to aqueous 4-nitrophenol in the absence of thin film catalyst led to deprotonation of the substrate (to 4-nitrophenoxide) with negligible reduction of the nitro group. No reaction was observed either when 4-nitrophenol and aqueous NaBH4 were put in contact with trimesic acid and melamine (which formed HOF in situ, entry 5 of Table 2 ) or with trimesic acid, melamine, 2-methylimidazole and [Zn(acac)2] (which formed ZIF-8@HOF in situ, entry 8 of Table 2) or with preformed (ex situ) ZIF-8@HOF (entry 8 of Table 2), indicating that, in the absence of platinum, the NaBH4 reduction of the nitro group does not take place. However, in the presence of platinum supported HOFs such as Pt(0)@HOF or Pt(0)-melamine, either formed mixing the suitable reagents in the quartz cuvette (in situ procedure, see experimental part) or added as preformed thin film (ex situ procedure), the reduction of the 4-nitrophenoxide to 4-aminophenoxide did occur and the reaction progress could be smoothly followed by UV–Vis spectroscopy (see details in Supplementary Information). Being in pseudo first order conditions (due to the great excess of NaBH4), the (-Ln) of absorbance (–Ln A) versus time plots gave the kinetic constants of the reaction which are collected in Table 2. The in situ prepared catalysts exhibited higher reaction rates for the 4-nitrophenol reduction than ex situ catalyst formation (Table 2), presumably due to the presence of all active sites on the surface of the thin film with no agglomeration. Also, the in situ prepared catalysts exhibited higher reaction rate than the reported porous structures or metallic catalysts (entries 13–22 of Table 2). Interestingly, our thin film catalysts in some cases were more effective than pure Pt, indicating an increased catalytic activity at reduced costs. The lack of reaction observed with the in situ prepared Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (entry 9) can be rationalized recalling that the pore diameters in the latter structure are 1.9 nm, too small to allow nitrophenol to enter the cavities of the catalyst. Moreover, comparing the average surface roughness of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (135.6 nm) with that of ZIF-8@HOF (176.4 nm) indicates that after platinization, the surface of the ZIF-8@HOF becomes smoother suggesting that Pt(0) nanoparticles are completely immersed in the cavity of ZIF-8 and not accessible to catalyse 4-nitrophenol reduction. In the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid, the ex situ procedure led to 4-nitrophenol reduction with a rate constant of 1.64·10–3 s–1 (Figure S15e,f) whereas the in situ procedure (Figure S15a-c) led to the removal of 4-nitrophenol from the water medium by progressive formation, with trimesic acid, of a new HOF with the structure shown in Fig. 12 . In this case, the apparent rate constant measured by UV–Vis spectroscopy (5.99·10–3 s–1) measures the rate of disappearing of 4-nitrophenol from the water medium and not the reduction rate, as in the case of the ex situ procedure. Removal of 4-nitrophenol (and not reduction to 4-aminophenol) was observed also in the cases of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (ex situ strategy) and Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film (in situ strategy). The activity and specificity of the platinized HOFs in the 4-nitrophenol reduction/ removal from water medium is summarized in Fig. 13 . Generally, to explain the 4-nitrophenol reduction mechanism, Langmuir-Hinshelwood model is applied with these steps: (i) adsorption of 4-nitrophenol and BH4 − on the catalyst surface, (ii) reaction progress and (iii) formation of 4-aminophenol and desorption that explain in Figure S22. According to the Eq. (1), adsorption of BH4 − on the surface of the catalyst is the first step: (1) BH 4 − + catalyst → adsorb BH 4 − − catalyst Reduction of water into H2 and formation of active hydrogen is the second step (Eq. (2)): (2) BH 4 − − catalyst + H 2 O → k H BO 2 − − catalyst + H − catalyst It is considerable that the adsorption or desorption of 4-nitrophenol (Eq. (3)) and BH4 − from the surface of catalyst are very fast, so on the kinetic equation, they do not appear. (3) 4 − nitrophenol + catalyst → k 4 − N P − 1 k 4 − N P 4 − nitrophenol − catalyst Conversion of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol and desorption is the last step (Eqs. (4) and (5)). The rate determining step (RDS) is illustrated in Eq. (4). (4) 4 − nitrophenol − catalyst → k 4 − aminophenol − catalyst + H 2 O (5) 4 − aminophenol − catalyst → desorb 4 − aminophenol + catalyst Fig. 14 (a-c) shows a possible pathway for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol on the surface of Pt(0)@HOF thin film, the most active catalyst among those considered in Table 2. Addition of sodium borohydride to the biphasic system leads to the formation of Pt(0) nanoparticles on the porous structure of HOF which further react with NaBH4 to give Pt hydrides (Fig. 14b). The 4-nitrophenol trapped in the cavity of the HOF structure (with formation of inclusion complexes) via the π-π stacking interactions can be progressively reduced by the metal hydrides to 4-nitrosophenol, 4-hydroxylaminophenol and finally 4-hydroxylaniline [75] (Fig. 14c). Once formed, 4-hydroxylaniline detaches from the Pt(0)@HOF surface. Figure S23 (a-c) shows the 4-nitrophenol reduction/ removal details in the presence of in situ-formed (a) Pt(0)@HOF, (b) Pt(0)-trimesic acid and (c) Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films. In the case of Pt(0)@HOF catalyst, trimesic acid and melamine form the HOF structure at the quartz cuvette interface (Figure S23a, i). Then, 4-nitrophenol molecules are immobilized on the porous HOF structure via a weak hydrogen bond (Figure S23a, ii) followed by the entrance of this molecule to the HOF cavity and formation of inclusion complex. In fact, the cavities of the HOF structure play a role in trapping the 4-nitrophenol pollutant via a π-π stacking interaction between HOF and 4-nitrophenol, while degradation is done by Pt(0) nanoparticles that is very effective in increasing the reduction rate. Addition of the reducing agent causes the formation of both Pt(0) nanoparticles on the HOF and 4-nitrophenoxide (Figure S23a, iii). Finally, the reduction process occurs on the surface of the catalyst and aminophenol is separated from the surface as a reaction product (Figure S23a, iv). Comparing the average surface roughness of HOF (123.9 nm) with Pt(0)@HOF thin film (323.1 nm) indicates the presence of a part of nanoparticles on the porous surface of the HOF structure and these particles are not completely immersed in the cavity or covered, that is why the reduction process is easily done (Figure S23a, iv). Also, comparing the pore diameter of the Pt(0)@HOF structure (8.5 nm) with the diameter of the 4-nitrophenol molecule indicates that the 4-nitrophenol molecule has the ability to enter the cavity of this porous structure easily and trapped. In Figure S23 (b, i), aqueous solution of trimesic acid and 4-nitrophenol form new HOF structures by hydrogen bonding at the interface of the quartz cuvette (Figure S23b, ii). Therefore, the 4-nitrophenol concentration is decreased. By the addition of sodium borohydride, just Pt(0) nanoparticles is formed. 4-Nitrophenol is involved with trimesic acid, so no 4-nitrophenoxide is produced (Figure S23b, iii). Pt-trimesic acid thin film displayed the average surface roughness of 64.4 nm and mean pore diameter of 10.5 nm. The removal is happened in this situation (Figure S23b, iv). In the case of Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film, no reduction/ removal is happened. HOF is formed from the trimesic acid and melamine mixture followed by the formation of primitive ZIF-8 crystals at the interface in the cuvette (Figure S23c, i). ZIF-8 crystals are interpenetrated in the HOF crystal structure and tune the pore diameters (Figure S23c, ii). Addition of the reducing agent led to the Pt(0) nanoparticles formation encapsulated in the ZIF-8 porous structure in addition to the 4-nitrophenoxide ion formation (Figure S23c, iii). Comparing the average surface roughness of ZIF-8@HOF (176.4 nm) with Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (135.6 nm) confirms that the surface become smoother after the formation of Pt(0) nanoparticles. Therefore, it can be concluded that nanoparticles are completely immersed in the cavity of ZIF-8 and covered (Figure S23c, iv). Lower catalytic activity is predicted due to this fact. Also, comparing the pore diameter of the Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF structure (1.9 nm) with the pore diameter of HOF (7.1 nm) shows that addition of ZIF-8 tunes the pore diameter and form cavities with lower pore diameters. Furthermore, comparing the pore diameter of the Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF structure (1.9 nm) with the diameter of the 4-nitrophenol molecule indicates that the 4-nitrophenol molecule cannot enter to the cavity of this porous structure easily, in comparison with Pt(0)@HOF structure, (Figure S23c, iv), so, the reaction is not progressed in the presence of this catalyst, despite increasing the stability of this structure via the synergy of π-π interactions between aromatic rings and hydrogen bonds [76,77]. These data are for the in situ catalyst formation and 4-nitrophenol removal. In the case of freshly prepared catalysts, ordinary reduction was almost happened for 4-nitrophenol. Tuning the size of the cavity has a good function in specializing the activity of the catalyst for trapping the particles. The percentage of conversion is measured for some of the as-synthesized catalysts (see details in Supplementary Information). Also, the reusability of the catalysts was investigated in the case of ex situ catalytic strategy which is a key fact in order to convert the toxic 4-nitrophenol to less toxic and applicable compounds in industry. The reusability of Pt(0)@HOF, Pt(0)-trimesic acid and Pt(0)-melamine thin films were evaluated for consecutive cycle and display in Figure S24 (see details in Supplementary Information). 3.9.2 Methanol oxidation in fuel cells Direct methanol fuel cells with platinum electrocatalysts exhibit considerable potential for portable/static applications, but the high cost (more than 50 % cost of the fuel cell) and poisoning of platinum active sites restricted the progress of this new energy source. The HOF-based structures described above were applied as electrocatalysts for methanol oxidation by covering the surface of the working electrode of the electrochemical cell with the desired thin film. Cyclic voltammograms were recorded in 0.50 M H2SO4 and CH3OH in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF electrocatalysts and 0.50 M NaOH and CH3OH in the case of ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films. In the cyclic voltammograms recorded with Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film in 0.50 M H2SO4 medium (Fig. 15 a, i), the characteristic peaks in regions I and IV are due to desorption and adsorption of atomic hydrogen on the surface of the catalyst and the characteristic peaks in regions II and III are due to PtO formation and PtO reduction, respectively. The figures of merit determined for the electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol with HOF-based structures are listed in Table 3 . The values of the maximum current densities (a parameter directly related to electrocatalytic activity) recorded with Pt(0)-trimesic acid (159 mA cm–2, entry 1), Pt(0)-melamine (144 mA cm–2, entry 2) and Pt(0)@HOF (172 mA cm–2, entry3) thin films were higher than pure Pt(0) thin film (31 mA cm–2, entry 10) [78] or other metallic nanocatalysts in the acidic medium (entries 14–15). ZIF-8@HOF (83 mA cm–2, entry 4) and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF (47 mA cm–2, entry 5) thin films exhibited higher maximum current densities in comparison with ZIF-8 thin film (33 mA cm–2, entry 6) [51] or Pt(0)@ZIF-8 (43 mA cm–2, entry 7) [39] in alkaline media (Table 3). Another parameter directly related to electrocatalytic activity is mass activity. Comparing the mass activity (equation S2) obtained for Pt(0)@HOF thin film (741 mA mg–1, entry 3) with Pt(0) thin film (48 mA mg–1, entry 10) [78] confirms a better electrocatalytic activity of Pt(0)@HOF. Higher mass activity was also shown by Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film (334 mA mg–1, entry 5) in comparison with Pt(0)@ZIF-8 thin film (119 mA mg–1, entry 7) [39]. The stability of the as-prepared thin films during the methanol oxidation and in the electrolyte medium was investigated by cycling tests. Fig. 15e, i and S25b-e, i display 100 continuous cycles for Pt(0)@HOF, Pt(0)-melamine, Pt(0)-trimesic acid, ZIF-8@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin films, which revealed a substantial stability of the as-synthesized electrocatalysts in the reaction medium. The related voltammograms recorded after the cycling tests (scan rate = 50 mV/s) are shown in Fig. 15e, ii and S25b-e, ii. The cyclic voltammograms in the acidic medium exhibited the maximum peak in the forward scan (Jf ) attributed to methanol oxidation and the maximum peak in the backward scan (Jb ) attributed to the CO oxidation (Fig. 15 (a-b, ii) and S25a, ii). The Jf /Jb ratio can be used to evaluate the tolerance of electrocatalysts against poisoning with CO [78]. A larger Jf /Jb ratio in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid (2.7), Pt(0)-melamine (4.7) and Pt(0)@HOF (1.4) electrocatalysts than Pt(0) nanostructured thin film (1.3) [78] or even commercial-Pt/C (0.6) [79,80] confirm a better tolerance and a more complete methanol oxidation in the presence of these thin films (Table 3). The long-term poisoning rate (δ) is another factor useful to evaluate the stability of the electrocatalysts against poisoning in the reaction medium and is calculated from chronoamperometric curves applying equation S3 (Fig. 15f). A lower value for δ means a lower rate of poisoning of the active sites. Chronoamperometric analysis was carried out for (i) Pt(0)-melamine, (ii) Pt(0)-trimesic acid, (iii) Pt(0)@HOF thin films in the electrolyte medium of 0.50 M H2SO4 and CH3OH and (iv) Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film in the electrolyte medium of 0.50 M NaOH and CH3OH for 1200s at room temperature. The obtained values in the case of Pt(0)-trimesic acid (0.025 % s–1), Pt(0)-melamine (0.055 % s−1), and Pt(0)@HOF (0.025 % s–1) thin films are comparable with that of Pt/C (0.096 % s–1) [81], (PtPdCu/C 0.084 % s–1) [81], (PtPdCuIr/C 0.061 % s–1) [81] and (PtRuIr/C 0.13 % s–1) [82] in acidic medium (Table 3). The long-term poisoning rate calculated for Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF (0.012 % s–1) is comparable with that of ZIF-8 thin film (0.1 % s–1) [51] or (Pt/C ∼ 0.1 % s–1) [83] in alkaline medium (Table 3). The obtained results indicate that HOF-based thin films exhibit acceptable tolerance during the methanol oxidation process. The thermodynamic tendency and stability of the electrocatalysts against corrosion in the reaction medium can be evaluated from the open circuit potential (OCP), being the lower the OCP value, the greater the corrosion of the electrocatalyst in the electrolyte medium. Comparing the OCP values reported in Table 3 it can be deduced that ZIF-8@HOF thin film is more stable against corrosion in alkaline medium in comparison with ZIF-8 [51] or Pt(0)@ZIF-8 [39] thin films. Linear polarization curves were recorded for (i) Pt(0)@HOF, (ii) Pt(0)-melamine, (iii) Pt(0)-trimesic acid, (iv) Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF and (v) ZIF-8@HOF thin films (Fig. 15g) to measure the corrosion current (Icorr). Lower values for the corrosion current in the case of (ZIF-8@HOF 0.04 µA) and (Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF 0.02 µA) thin films in comparison with (ZIF-8 thin film 0.15 µA) [51] or (Pt(0)@ZIF-8 thin films 0.12, 0.17 µA) [39] (Table 3) are evidence of a milder corrosion process. The J-V curves reported in Fig. 15h (for ZIF-8@HOF thin film) and in Figure S25f-i for the other HOF systems) in alkaline medium were used to calculate the power from the knee part. The values of the maximum power obtained for the HOF systems are reported in Table 3 and anticipate for these electrocatalysts a good performance in electronic devices and industry. The electron transfer efficiency was investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in the case of ZIF-8@HOF thin film (Fig. 15i) and compared with ZIF-8. Solution resistance (Rs) and charge transfer resistance (Rct), obtained from the initial point of the semicircle and semicircle diameter, respectively, are the following. Rs: ZIF-8 149 Ω [39], ZIF-8@HOF 140 Ω; Rct: ZIF-8 181.5 Ω [39], ZIF-8@HOF 129.5 Ω, being the lower Rct the lower resistance and the better charge transfer. Finally, the initial potential of oxidation is another fact that is important. Generally, the lower initial oxidation potential in the presence of a catalyst means that the reaction is progressing easier and the catalyst is more effective. These values are (Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film 0.69 V), (Pt(0)-melamine thin film 0.68 V) and (Pt(0)@HOF thin film 0.66 V) in comparison with (Pt(0) thin film 0.73 V), (Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF thin film 0.90 V) in comparison with (Pt(0)@ZIF-8 thin film 1.19 V) and are illustrated in Table 3. 4 Conclusions In this study, the thermal and chemical stability of six self-assembled HOFs thin films were improved by penetration of platinum nanoparticles into the trimesic acid-based HOF porous structure and formation of: (i) metallized HOF thin film (Pt@HOF thin film); (ii) interpenetrated frameworks of zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (Pt@ZIF-8@HOF thin film); (iii) π-π stacking interactions of 2-methylimidazole (Pt@2-methylimidazole@HOF thin film). Self-assembly at toluene-water interface led to the formation of thin films with considerable activity in the reduction/ removal of 4-nitrophenol from water medium (either by adsorption/ incorporation into the HOF structures or by reduction to 4-aminophenol) and in the methanol oxidation process of fuel cells. Platinum supported HOFs such as Pt(0)@HOF and Pt(0)-melamine, either formed mixing the suitable reagents in the quartz cuvette (in situ procedure) or added as preformed thin film (ex situ procedure) facilitated the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol with rate constants ranging from 0.75·10–3 s–1 (for Pt(0)@HOF, ex situ) to 10.81·10–3 s–1 (for Pt(0)@HOF, in situ). In methanol oxidation process and mimicking the anode half-cell of direct methanol fuel cell, the platinized thin films (Pt(0)@HOF, Pt(0)@2-methylimidazole@HOF and Pt(0)@ZIF-8@HOF) showed better current densities, stability, long term poisoning rates and corrosion currents than ZIF-8, Pt(0)@ZIF-8 and even Pt(0) thin films. The findings presented in this study contribute to the growing body of knowledge on self-assembled HOF-based catalysts and their potential for addressing toxic 4-nitrophenol reduction and energy challenges. By understanding the mechanisms underlying their catalytic performance, further advancements can be made in designing efficient and sustainable catalysts for a wide range of applications. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks (HOFs) are pure organic framework structures endowed with appropriate flexibility and porosity, which have attracted special attention in the field of energy and water, air, and soil remediation. In this study, six HOF-based materials were synthesized as thin film at the liquid/liquid (toluene/water) interface and characterized by FT-IR, Raman, UV–Vis, PXRD, ICP, AFM, SEM, TGA, and BET techniques. The self-assembled HOF-based thin films were employed as catalysts for the 4-nitrophenol removal from water medium and, for the first time, for methanol oxidation of fuel cell, with satisfying results. Simultaneous in situ catalyst formation and 4-nitrophenol reduction occurred in the case of Pt(0)@HOF thin film, but an extraordinary removal (not reduction) occurred in the presence of Pt(0)-trimesic acid thin film by formation of a new HOF from trimesic acid and 4-nitrophenol. Successful reduction of 4-nitrophenol occurred also in the presence of freshly prepared Pt(0)-trimesic acid, Pt(0)-melamine and Pt(0)@HOF catalysts (ex situ strategy). The chemical and thermal stability of HOF structure was improved by the interpenetration of ZIF-8 crystal structure, by increasing the hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking in the presence of 2-methylimidazole. The interpenetration of ZIF-8 to the crystal structure of HOF caused a significant decrease of the pore diameter of the structure. These pores acted as specific sites for the guest molecules, and their dimensions did not permit 4-nitrophenol to penetrate into the cavity of structures whereas allowed methanol penetration into these cavities due to its smaller size.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing catalytic activity through self-assembled hydrogen-bonded organic framework-based catalysts at liquid/liquid interface for 4-nitrophenol reduction and energy challenges in methanol fuel cell
